questions.text: Which of the following is the best study design as per the hierarchy of evidence?

Arrange the steps of experimental studies:
A) Blinding
B) Randomization
C) Defining inclusion exclusion criteria
D) Statistical analysis
You have gone to a village for screening where people have diabetes and hypertension. Which type of screening is done for family members who show up in large numbers?
questions.solution:
• Mass screening: - Simply means the screening of a whole population or a sub group. It is offered to all, irrespective of the particular risk individual may run of contracting the disease in question.
  • High-risk or selective screening: - Applied selectively to high-risk groups, the groups defined on the basis of epidemiological research. For example, since cancer cervix tends to occur relatively less often in the upper social groups, screening for cancer cervix in the lower social groups can increase the yield of new cases. One population sub-group where certain diseases (diabetes, hypertension, breast cancer) tend to be aggregated in the family, so by detecting the other members of the family the physician can detect additional cases.
  • Multiphasic screening: - It has been defined as the application of two or more screening test in combination to a large number of people at one time rather than to carry out separate screening tests for single diseases.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Multiphasic screening - Incorrect
Multiphasic screening involves conducting multiple screening tests at once for various diseases in a large population. While this may be useful in public health settings, the scenario described focuses on individuals with a specific familial risk, making high-risk screening the better choice.

Choice B: Mass screening - Incorrect
Mass screening refers to testing an entire population or a large subgroup regardless of individual risk factors. The scenario specifies that screening is being done for family members of affected individuals, which aligns with high-risk rather than mass screening.

Choice D: Anonymous screening - Incorrect
Anonymous screening is conducted without collecting identifying information about individuals being tested. This is typically used in diseases with social stigma, such as HIV/AIDS, rather than in a familial setting for diabetes and hypertension.

Key Takeaway

High-risk screening is the most appropriate approach for screening family members of individuals with diabetes and hypertension since these diseases have a strong familial aggregation.

choices.text: Men who have sex with men

questions.text: In public health, which of the following is not included in the high-risk core population for HIV transmission?
questions.solution:
• For doing HIV sentinel surveillance the target population is divided in to three groups:
  • High-risk core population which includes intravenous drug users, men who have sex with men, female sex workers, and transgenders.
  • Bridge population which includes long distance truck drivers, single male migrants.
  • General population: pregnant women attending ANC clinic.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: IV Drug users - Incorrect
Intravenous drug users (IDUs) are considered part of the high-risk core population due to shared needle use, which significantly increases the risk of HIV transmission.

Choice B: Female sex workers - Incorrect
Female sex workers (FSWs) are classified under the high-risk core population because of frequent unprotected sexual encounters with multiple partners, increasing their vulnerability to HIV.

Choice D: Men who have sex with men - Incorrect
Men who have sex with men (MSM) are included in the high-risk core population due to the high prevalence of HIV transmission in this group, often linked to unprotected anal intercourse.

Key Takeaway

The high-risk core population for HIV transmission includes intravenous drug users, female sex workers, men who have sex with men, and transgenders, while long-distance truck drivers belong to the bridge population as they connect high-risk groups with the general population.

questions.text: Which of the following is a water-based disease?
questions.solution:
• HAV: - The major route for this transmission is faecal-oral route. It may occur by direct contact or indirectly by way of contaminated water, food, or milk.
  • HBV: - Can be transmitted by parenteral route, perinatal transmission, and sexual transmission.
  • HCV: - Through contaminated blood transfusions, blood products and organ transplants, injections given with contaminated syringes and needle stick injuries in health care settings, injection drug use, being born to a hepatitis C infected mother.
  • HDV: - Routes of transmission are the same as for HBV.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice B: HBV - Incorrect
Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is not waterborne; it is transmitted via parenteral routes, perinatal transmission, and sexual contact. It spreads through contaminated blood, unprotected sexual contact, and from mother to child during childbirth.

Choice C: HCV - Incorrect
Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is transmitted primarily through contaminated blood products, injection drug use, and unsafe medical procedures. It is not associated with waterborne transmission.

Choice D: HDV - Incorrect
Hepatitis D virus (HDV) has the same transmission routes as HBV, requiring HBV infection for replication. It spreads through bloodborne and sexual transmission, not through water.

Key Takeaway

Among hepatitis viruses, HAV is the only one classified as a waterborne disease, spreading via the fecal-oral route, whereas HBV, HCV, and HDV are transmitted through bloodborne and sexual routes.

questions.text: Malaria detection on the field is done by which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Two types of blood tests are useful in searching for and identification of malaria parasite. The thick film and the thin film. It is recommended that both types of film be prepared on a single microscopic slide. The thick film is more reliable in searching for parasite. The thin slide is more valuable for identifying the species of the parasite present.
  • Rapid diagnostic tests are based on the detection of circulating parasite antigens with a simple dipstick format.
  • Those who live very close to the laboratory will need to do only the slide test, because it will be possible to get the test result from the laboratory on the same day or, at the most, the next day.
  • Those who live far from the laboratory should do both the tests, RDT and slide, from a single finger prick. You will be able to first read the RDT result within 15 minutes.
  • If the RDT is positive, you know that the person has falciparum malaria. You should give treatment for falciparum malaria. You need not send the slide to the laboratory.
  • If the RDT is negative, you know the person does not have falciparum malaria, but you do not know whether the person has the less dangerous form, vivax malaria, or not. Hence, you should send the slide to the laboratory and wait for the result. You can wait, because you know that the person does not have the dangerous form of malaria.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Thick Smear - Incorrect
Thick blood smears are highly sensitive for detecting malaria parasites but require microscopy, which is not ideal for field detection due to the need for trained personnel and laboratory infrastructure.

Choice B: Thin Smear - Incorrect
Thin smears are useful for species identification but are less sensitive than thick smears. Like thick smears, they require a laboratory setting and expert interpretation, making them impractical for immediate field diagnosis.

Choice D: Quantitative Buffy Coat - Incorrect
Quantitative Buffy Coat (QBC) is an automated test that uses fluorescent staining to detect malaria parasites in the buffy coat layer of centrifuged blood. However, it requires specialized equipment and is not suited for field use.

Key Takeaway

For field detection of malaria, RDTs (HRP2 antigen-based tests) are the preferred method due to their speed, ease of use, and ability to diagnose Plasmodium falciparum without laboratory infrastructure.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in uncomplicated falciparum malaria management?
questions.solution:
• Dose schedule for treatment of uncomplicated P. Falciparum cases:
  • Artemisinin based combination therapy (ACT-SP)- Artesunate 4 mg/kg body weight for 3 days, plus Sulfadoxine (25 mg/kg body weight) - pyrimethamine (1.25 mg/kg body weight) on the first
  • Primaquine .75 mg/kg body weight on day 2
  • In North- Eastern states:
  • ACT-AL co-formulated tablet of artemether (20mg) - Lumefantrine (120mg).
  • Primaquine 0.75 mg/kg body weight on day 2.
  • Treatment of uncomplicated P. Falciparum cases in pregnancy:
  • In the first trimester quinine salt 10 mg/kg 3 times daily for 7 days.
  • 2nd and 3rd trimester area-specific ACT as per dosage schedules.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Artesunate - Incorrect
Artesunate is a key component of ACT and is widely used in the treatment of uncomplicated P. falciparum malaria. It is given at 4 mg/kg body weight for 3 days in combination with Sulfadoxine-Pyrimethamine (SP) or other partner drugs.

Choice B: Artemether - Incorrect
Artemether is another artemisinin derivative used in ACT-based therapy. In some regions, artemether-lumefantrine (AL) is the preferred ACT for treating uncomplicated falciparum malaria.

Choice C: Primaquine - Incorrect
Primaquine is used in P. falciparum malaria to reduce transmission by killing gametocytes. The recommended dose is 0.75 mg/kg body weight on day 2.

Key Takeaway

Chloroquine is no longer recommended for uncomplicated P. falciparum malaria due to resistance. Instead, ACT (e.g., artesunate + sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine or artemether-lumefantrine) and primaquine are used.

questions.text: All of the following help to prevent COVID-19
questions.solution:
• For prevention and treatment of COVID-19 following guidelines are there such as:
  • Strict implementation of isolation and quarantine guidelines.
  • The Government of India currently approved the vaccine like COVISHIELD and COVAXIN for routine use.
  • Hygienic measures such as handwashing after touching patients, use of appropriate and well-fitted masks, and infection control measures.
  • Regularly and thoroughly clean your hands with an alcohol-based hand rub or wash them with soap and water.
  • Avoid going to crowded places and maintain social distance and wear mask.
  • Avoid touching eyes, nose and mouth as contaminated hands can transfer the virus to your eyes, nose or mouth. From there, the virus can enter in body and infect.
  • Screening of international travelers.
  • Timely and accurate reporting and sharing of information with other authorities.
  • Antivirals, interferon type 1, intravenous immunoglobulin and systemic corticosteroids are used in the treatment.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Masks - Incorrect
Masks reduce the transmission of respiratory droplets, which is the primary mode of COVID-19 spread. They are recommended, especially in crowded or enclosed spaces.

Choice B: Vaccines - Incorrect
COVID-19 vaccines (e.g., COVISHIELD, COVAXIN, mRNA vaccines) provide immunity and significantly reduce the risk of severe disease, hospitalization, and death.

Choice D: Cough etiquette - Incorrect
Practicing cough etiquette (e.g., covering mouth/nose with a tissue or elbow when coughing/sneezing) helps prevent the spread of respiratory viruses, including COVID-19.

Key Takeaway

Ivermectin is not an approved preventive measure for COVID-19. Effective preventive strategies include vaccination, mask-wearing, hygiene measures, social distancing, and cough etiquette.

choices.text: Purified, inactivated FDA approved vaccine is found to be helpful in prevention
Sexual abstinence, using condoms, delaying pregnancy is helpful in controlling the disease
Immunoglobulin and plasmapheresis is used in treatment of Zika

questions.text: Dr. Sara made a presentation on infectious diseases. She spoke about the prevention and treatment of Zika virus. which of the following is true with respect to the prevention of Zika virus?
questions.solution:
• Zika virus is primarily transmitted by infected mosquitoes of the Aedes(Stegomyia) genus, mainly Aedes aegypti, in tropical and subtropical regions. Aedes mosquitoes usually bite during the day. These mosquitoes also transmit dengue, chikungunya and urban yellow fever.
  • Zika virus is also transmitted from mother to fetus during pregnancy, as well as through sexual contact, transfusion of blood and blood products, and possibly through organ transplantation.
  • Protection against mosquito bites during the day and early evening is a key measure to prevent Zika virus infection, especially among pregnant women, women of reproductive age and young children.
  • WHO recommends practicing safer sex or abstinence for a period of three months for men and two months for women who are returning from areas of active Zika virus transmission to prevent infection of their sex partners. Sexual partners of pregnant women living in or returning from areas where local transmission of Zika virus occurs should practice safer sex or abstain from sexual activity throughout pregnancy.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Symptomatic treatment with NSAIDs - Incorrect
While Zika virus is primarily managed symptomatically, NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen, aspirin) are not recommended initially due to the risk of dengue co-infection, which may increase bleeding complications. Acetaminophen (paracetamol) is preferred.

Choice B: Purified, inactivated FDA-approved vaccine is found to be helpful in prevention - Incorrect
Currently, no FDA-approved Zika virus vaccine is available. While experimental vaccines are under development, none have been widely approved for public use.

Choice D: Immunoglobulin and plasmapheresis is used in treatment of Zika - Incorrect
There is no specific antiviral treatment for Zika virus. Immunoglobulin and plasmapheresis are not used in standard Zika management.

Key Takeaway

Preventing Zika virus infection involves avoiding mosquito bites, practicing safe sex, and delaying pregnancy in affected areas. No approved vaccine or specific antiviral treatment exists.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is not recommended after 65 years?
questions.solution:
The HPV vaccine is not recommended after 65 years because:

  • HPV infection is acquired early in life, and the vaccine is most effective before exposure to the virus, ideally between 9-26 years.
  • ACIP (Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices) recommends catch-up vaccination up to age 26, but not beyond 45 years, as older individuals are less likely to benefit.
  • Routine HPV vaccination is not recommended after 65 years unless there is a specific high-risk condition.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Influenza - Incorrect

  • Annual influenza vaccination is recommended for all adults, including those over 65 years, to reduce the risk of severe complications.
  • High-dose influenza vaccines or adjuvanted flu vaccines are specifically designed for older adults to provide better protection.

Choice B: Herpes Zoster - Incorrect

  • The Shingrix vaccine (recombinant zoster vaccine) is recommended for adults ≥50 years, including those over 65 years, to prevent shingles and postherpetic neuralgia.
  • Even individuals who had shingles or received the older Zostavax vaccine should get Shingrix.

Choice C: Pneumococcal - Incorrect

  • Pneumococcal vaccines (PCV20 or PCV15 + PPSV23) are recommended at age 65 to protect against pneumonia, meningitis, and sepsis caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • Revaccination may be required based on previous vaccination history.

Key Takeaway

HPV vaccination is not recommended after 65 years, whereas influenza, herpes zoster, and pneumococcal vaccines are essential for older adults.

questions.text: All are live vaccine except: -
questions.solution:
• Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant subunit vaccine, not a live vaccine.
  • It contains HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen) produced using recombinant DNA technology in yeast cells.
  • Since it is an inactivated (non-live) vaccine, it is safe for immunocompromised individuals and can be given to newborns.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Rotavirus - Incorrect

  • Rotavirus vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine.
  • Available as monovalent (Rotarix) or pentavalent (RotaTeq) formulations.
  • Given orally to protect against severe rotavirus gastroenteritis.

Choice C: Measles - Incorrect

  • Measles vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine (often given as part of the MMR or MMRV vaccine).
  • Provides long-term immunity against Measles, Mumps, and Rubella.

Choice D: Varicella - Incorrect

  • Varicella (chickenpox) vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine.
  • Helps prevent chickenpox and its complications.
  • Also used in Herpes Zoster vaccine (Shingrix is recombinant, Zostavax was live attenuated).

Key Takeaway

Hepatitis B is an inactivated recombinant vaccine, while Rotavirus, Measles, and Varicella vaccines are live attenuated.

questions.text: Which of the following will not induce the passive immune?
questions.solution:
• Active immunity can be acquired in 3 ways: -
  • Following clinical infection, e.g. chickenpox, rubella, and measles.
  • Following subclinical or inapparent infection e.g. polio and diphtheria.
  • Following immunization with an antigen which may be a killed vaccine, a live attenuated vaccine or toxoid.
  • Passive immunity can be acquired in 3 ways: -
  • By administration of an antibody containing preparation (immune globulin or antiserum).
  • By transfer of maternal antibodies across the placenta. Human milk also contains protective antibodies, (IgA).
  • By transfer of lymphocytes, to induce passive cellular immunity- this procedure is still experimental.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Monoclonal Antibody - Incorrect

  • Monoclonal antibodies provide passive immunity.
  • They are preformed antibodies given for immediate protection (e.g., Palivizumab for RSV, Rituximab for B-cell malignancies).

Choice B: IgA - Incorrect

  • IgA from breast milk provides passive immunity to newborns.
  • Helps protect against respiratory and gastrointestinal infections in early life.

Choice C: Anti-toxin - Incorrect

  • Anti-toxin provides passive immunity by neutralizing bacterial toxins.
  • Used in diseases like Tetanus and Diphtheria to provide immediate protection.

Key Takeaway

Toxoid induces active immunity by stimulating antibody production, whereas Monoclonal Antibodies, IgA, and Anti-toxins provide passive immunity.

questions.text: A pus swab has been sent for microbiological examination to your laboratory. After testing the sample how will you discard it?
questions.solution:
• Choice A : RED BAG: - This category basically contain waste that can be recycled such as tubings, bottles, catheters, IV tubes and sets, urine bag, syringes without needle, gloves etc.
  • Choice C : BLUE BAG: - This category contains METALLIC BODY IMPLANTS and GLASSWARES such as broken and discarded vials and ampoules except those containing cytotoxic wastes.
  • Choice B : YELLOW BAG: - Human anatomical waste such as organs, body part, placenta, dead foetus, Animal anatomical waste, Soiled waste such as items with blood and body fluids like swabs, plasters, bag containing residual residual or discarded blood or blood products, Chemical waste such as expired and cytotoxic drugs and medicines, Microbiology, biotechnology and other clinical laboratory waste. Along with this the PPE kits used in COVID-19 are also disposed in yellow colour bag.
  • WHITE BAG: - It is translucent, puncture proof, leak proof containers. Sharp objects such as needles, syringes with fixed needles, scalpels, blades etc.
  • Choice D: Black - Black bags are meant for general waste that is non-infectious, such as household-type waste and food waste from hospitals. Pus swabs contain potentially infectious material, so they must not be discarded in a black bag.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cold sterilization technique?
questions.solution:
Autoclaving is a heat-based sterilization method and not a cold sterilization technique.

It uses high-pressure steam at temperatures of 121°C to 134°C to kill microorganisms.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Plasma Sterilization - Incorrect

  • Plasma sterilization is a cold sterilization method that uses hydrogen peroxide gas plasma to kill microorganisms at low temperatures.
  • It is used for heat-sensitive medical instruments.

Choice B: UV Radiations - Incorrect

  • UV radiation is a non-thermal method of sterilization that damages microbial DNA.
  • It is commonly used for surface and air sterilization.

Choice D: Gamma Radiations - Incorrect

  • Gamma radiation is a cold sterilization method that kills microorganisms by breaking DNA strands.
  • It is used for sterilizing medical supplies, pharmaceuticals, and food products.

Key Takeaway

Cold sterilization techniques include plasma sterilization, UV radiation, and gamma radiation, whereas autoclaving is a heat-based sterilization method.

questions.text: ICER is a unit of which of the following economical analysis?
questions.solution:
• Analyst often judge whether or not a plan is cost effective or not by comparing its cost effectiveness through ICER.
  • ICER (Incremental Cost-Effectiveness Ratio) is a unit used in cost-effectiveness analysis (CEA) in economics. It is used to compare the relative costs and health outcomes of different interventions or treatments. ICER is calculated by dividing the difference in costs between two alternatives by the difference in their effectiveness.
  • This ratio helps in assessing whether the additional cost of one intervention is worth the additional benefit in terms of health outcomes.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Cost-Benefit Analysis - Incorrect

  • Cost-benefit analysis (CBA) assigns monetary value to both costs and benefits and compares them.
  • ICER is not used in CBA because it focuses on cost per unit of health outcome, not monetary benefits.

Choice C: Cost-Utility Analysis - Incorrect

  • Cost-utility analysis (CUA) measures cost per quality-adjusted life year (QALY) or disability-adjusted life year (DALY).
  • ICER is used in CEA, while CUA focuses on broader health outcomes.

Choice D: Cost-Margin Analysis - Incorrect

  • Cost-margin analysis is not a standard health economics evaluation method.

Key Takeaway

ICER is a key component of Cost-Effectiveness Analysis (CEA) used to evaluate the cost versus effectiveness of different healthcare interventions.

choices.text: Inequalities in distribution, adequate support and access to quality assured products only in low income settings
Purpose of UHC is to find the balance between countries' income, health provision and financial burden
Provide healthcare to everyone regardless of country's income
UHC only deals with the financial aspect of the health and cannot cover health provision to all

questions.text: Universal Health Coverage means that all people and communities receive the quality healthcare they need without any financial hardship. Which of the following are the challenges to implement the UHC?
questions.solution:
• Universal Health Coverage (UHC) aims to ensure all individuals receive essential healthcare services without financial hardship.
  • However, implementing UHC across all income levels is a challenge due to:
    • Limited healthcare infrastructure in low-income countries.
    • Financial constraints on government health budgets.
    • Variability in healthcare policies and resource allocation.
  • UHC must be tailored to a country's financial capacity while ensuring equity in access.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Inequalities in distribution, adequate support, and access to quality-assured products only in low-income settings - Incorrect

  • Inequalities in healthcare exist in both low- and high-income countries.
  • Access to quality-assured medications and medical products is a challenge globally, not just in low-income settings.

Choice B: Purpose of UHC is to find the balance between countries' income, health provision, and financial burden - Incorrect

  • This statement correctly describes one of the goals of UHC, but it is not a challenge in itself.
  • UHC implementation struggles not only with financial balance but also with workforce shortages, infrastructure, and policy gaps.

Choice D: UHC only deals with the financial aspect of health and cannot cover health provision to all - Incorrect

  • UHC covers both financial protection and healthcare service delivery to ensure people receive essential health services.
  • It includes preventive, curative, rehabilitative, and palliative care services, not just financial protection.

Key Takeaway

The challenge of UHC is not just providing healthcare to all but ensuring sustainable financing, equitable distribution, and adequate healthcare infrastructure based on a country's resources.

questions.text: A student went on a trip to Jaisalmer where the temperature was 40°C and the relative humidity was 20%. What will be the mechanism of heat loss?
questions.solution:
• Evaporation: - About 27% of the heat is lost by evaporation from the skin, mucous membranes and respiratory passages. It occurs in 2 forms: a) By Perspiration: - Perspiration occurs due to continuous diffusion of fluid through the epidermis. It occurs over the whole of the body surface at uniform rate and is largely independent of environmental conditions. This heat loss is not under control and therefore, cannot be changed as required. b) Evaporation of sweat: - Thermal sweating from eccrine sweat glands increases when the external or internal body temperature rise. Sweat is vaporized from the skin, which decreases its temperature. Evaporation decreases to a great extent if the humidity of the atmosphere is high.
  • Radiation: - Refers to transfer of heat from an object to another object with which it is not in contact. The magnitude of heat loss by radiation depends on the size of body surface and the average temperature difference between skin and surrounding objects.
  • Conduction: - Refers to heat exchange between objects at different temperatures that are in contact with one another. The amount of heat transferred by conduction is proportionate to the temperature difference between two objects.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice B: Radiation - Incorrect

  • Radiation is a major heat loss mechanism in cooler environments, where heat transfers from the body to cooler surroundings.
  • In Jaisalmer's high temperature (40°C), the environment is hotter than or equal to skin temperature, so radiative heat loss is minimal or even reversed (heat gain from surroundings).

Choice C: Conduction with air - Incorrect

  • Conduction occurs when heat is transferred through direct contact.
  • Air is a poor conductor of heat and, in hot climates, does not effectively cool the body unless wind enhances convective heat loss (which is different from conduction).

Choice D: Conduction with objects - Incorrect

  • Conduction with objects occurs when the body touches cooler surfaces (e.g., lying on a cool floor).
  • In hot desert conditions, surrounding surfaces are also hot, so conduction does not significantly contribute to heat loss.

Key Takeaway

In high-temperature, low-humidity environments, evaporation is the most effective heat loss mechanism, as sweat readily evaporates, removing body heat efficiently.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in heat exhaustion?
questions.solution:
• Unlike heat stroke, heat exhaustion is not because of failure of thermo-regulation.
  • It is a milder illness than heat stroke and is caused primarily by the imbalance or inadequate replacement of water and salts lost in perspiration due to thermal stress.
  • Heat exhaustion typically occurs after several days of high temperature.
  • Body temperature may be normal or moderately elevated, but it is uncommon to exceed 102 degree F.
  • The symptoms primarily dizziness, weakness, fatigue are those of circulatory distress.
  • Treatment is directed towards normalizing fluid and electrolyte balance.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice B: Altered sensorium - Incorrect

  • Mild confusion, dizziness, and fatigue can occur due to circulatory insufficiency and dehydration.
  • However, severe neurological impairment (e.g., coma, seizures) is a hallmark of heat stroke, not heat exhaustion.

Choice C: Orthostatic hypotension - Incorrect

  • Heat exhaustion leads to dehydration, causing reduced blood volume and orthostatic hypotension (drop in blood pressure upon standing).
  • Symptoms include dizziness, weakness, and fainting when standing up.

Choice D: Core body temperature below 105°F - Incorrect

  • In heat exhaustion, body temperature remains below 105°F (40°C).
  • In contrast, heat stroke presents with a core temperature above 105°F due to thermoregulatory failure.

Key Takeaway

Heat exhaustion is a milder form of heat illness where thermoregulation remains functional. The main causes are dehydration and electrolyte imbalance, with symptoms like dizziness, weakness, and orthostatic hypotension. In contrast, heat stroke is a medical emergency with thermoregulatory failure and a core temperature exceeding 105°F.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in SAM?
questions.solution:
• Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is defined by very low weight for height/length (Z-score below -3SD of the median WHO child growth standards), a mid-upper arm circumference <115 mm, or by the presence of nutritional oedema.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Low weight for height - Incorrect

  • Low weight for height (Z-score below -3SD) is a defining criterion for SAM.
  • This measurement indicates wasting, which is a sign of acute malnutrition.

Choice C: Pedal Edema - Incorrect

  • Bilateral nutritional edema (kwashiorkor) is a diagnostic feature of SAM.
  • It occurs due to protein deficiency and hypoalbuminemia, leading to fluid retention.

Choice D: Mid-upper arm circumference - Incorrect

  • MUAC <115 mm is a key diagnostic marker of SAM in children aged 6-59 months.
  • It is used in field settings where weight and height measurements are impractical.

Key Takeaway

SAM is characterized by very low weight-for-height (wasting), mid-upper arm circumference <115 mm, or nutritional edema. Low height-for-age (stunting) is a sign of chronic malnutrition, not acute malnutrition, and is therefore not included in the SAM criteria.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the Anemia Mukt Bharat programme?
questions.solution:
• Anemia Mukt Bharat was launched in 2018 to achieve the envisaged target of 3% reduction in anemia prevalence every year under the POSHAN Abhiyan.
  • The strategy recommends 6x6x6 strategy to reduce anemia prevalence in six age groups (6 beneficiaries) namely pre-school children (6-59 months), children (5-9 years), adolescent girls and boys (10-19 years), pregnant women, lactating women, and in women of reproductive age group (15-49 years) in programme mode through life cycle approach.
  • 6 interventions under this strategy are iron folic acid supplementation, periodic deworming, intensified year-round behavior change communication campaign including delayed cord clamping, testing and treatment of anemia using digital methods and point of care treatment, mandatory provision of iron folic acid fortified foods in public health programme and addressing non-nutritional causes of anemia in endemic pockets, with special focus on malaria, hemoglobinopathies and fluorosis.
  • The six institutional mechanisms are inter-ministerial coordination, national Anemia Mukt Bharat unit, national centre of excellence and advanced research on anemia control, convergence with other ministries, strengthening supply chain and logistics, Anemia Mukt Bharat dashboard and digital portal-one-stop shop for anemia.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: 6 beneficiaries - Incorrect

  • The program targets six specific age groups:
    1. Pre-school children (6-59 months)
    2. Children (5-9 years)
    3. Adolescent girls and boys (10-19 years)
    4. Pregnant women
    5. Lactating women
    6. Women of reproductive age (15-49 years)

Choice C: 6 interventions - Incorrect

  • The six core interventions of AMB include:
    1. Iron and folic acid (IFA) supplementation
    2. Periodic deworming
    3. Intensified behavior change campaigns
    4. Delayed cord clamping
    5. Testing and treatment of anemia using digital methods
    6. Provision of iron-folic acid-fortified foods and addressing non-nutritional anemia causes

Choice D: 6 Institutional mechanisms - Incorrect

  • The six institutional mechanisms ensuring program implementation are:
    1. Inter-ministerial coordination
    2. National AMB unit
    3. National Centre of Excellence for anemia control
    4. Convergence with other ministries
    5. Strengthening supply chain logistics
    6. AMB dashboard & digital portal

Key Takeaway

The Anemia Mukt Bharat program follows a 6x6x6 approach, which includes six beneficiary groups, six key interventions, and six institutional mechanisms. However, there is no component of "6 health functionaries," making it the incorrect option.
